*_pi_* — open-source path integral Monte Carlo program

This is a quantum simulation program from the 
[http://physics.asu.edu/shumway Shumway Research Group], which focuses on applications to nanoscience and technology.
A live version of the code is available as the application [http://www.nanohub.org/tools/pimc/ “pimc” on the NCN Purdue nanoHUB].
The current source code is available from  
[http://code.google.com/p/pi-qmc  project pi-qmc on Google code].
The program is object-oriented with [http://physics.asu.edu/shumway/codes/doc/pi/index.html Doxygen markup] and features flexible XML input format, as described in the [[pimc.xml Reference Guide]].

==Introduction to the PIMC method==
A good starting place is David Ceperley's review article on path integrals for superfluid helium,
  * D. M. Ceperley, [http://prola.aps.org/abstract/RMP/v67/i2/p279_1 “Path integrals in the theory of condensed helium,” Rev. Mod. Phys. '''67''', 279–355 (1995)].
The path integral approach to quantum statistical physics is described in many books, including
<ul>
<li><a href="http://books.google.com/books?id=4YDfQAYrkjkC">Feynman's Statistical Physics</a> and</li>
<li><a href="http://books.google.com/books?id=VwG0AAAACAAJ"> A. Zee's Quantum Field Theory in a Nutshell</a>.</li>
</ul>

==Tutorials==

===Built in demos===
You can run demos in the <code>pi</code> with automatically generated scripts. To get started, run <code>pi --demo</code>. This shows you a list of available demos.
To generate an input file for a simple harmonic oscillator, type <code>pi --demo=SHO</code>. This generates an input file <code>sho.xml</code> which you can run with <code>pi sho.xml</code>.

Currently available demos include:
;     SHO            :      A simple harmonic oscillator
;     H_atom       :        A hydrogen atom
;     [[Helium Atom Demo| He_atom]]      :        A helium atom
;     spin              :   A single spin in a magnetic field
;     [[Quantum Wire Demo| wire]]               :  10 electrons in a quasi-1D GaAs (2D) wire
